['George Orwell (author of "Animal Farm" and "1984") - Although he did not exclusively write about pig meat, Orwell\'s works often touch on the subject of farm animals and their treatment.', 'E.B', 'Michael Pollan (journalist and author of "The Omnivore\'s Dilemma" and "In Defense of Food") - While not exclusively focused on pig meat, Pollan\'s work often explores the ethical and environmental implications of food production and consumption.', 'Jonathan Safran Foer (author of "Eating Animals") - In this book, Foer explores the ethics of eating animals through a focus on factory farming and the treatment of pigs and other livestock.', 'Alice Walker (author of "The Color Purple") - While not primarily known for writing about food or agriculture, Walker\'s work often touches on themes of social justice and the interconnectedness of all living beings.', 'Wendell Berry ( poet and essayist) - Berry is a prominent voice in the movement for sustainable agriculture and has written extensively about the importance of small-scale, local food production.', 'Mark Kurlansky (author of "The Omnivore\'s Dilemma" and "Blood and Soil") - Kurlansky\'s work often explores the cultural and historical context of food and agriculture, including the role of pigs in human society.', 'Gary Saitz (author of "Pork: The Untold Story of the Bizarre and Fascinating Currency of the Global Economy") - Saitz\'s book explores the strange and complex ways in which pig meat has shaped human history and culture.']
